MDCT SCAN OF THE NECK
   
History: Right preauricular mass for 2 months, FNA---> suspicious for high grade mucoepidermoid CA

Technique: Plain and enhanced axial CT scans of the neck were performed with 1.0 mm slice thickness from the skull base to the root of neck with coronal and sagittal reconstruction.
                       
Findings:
The study shows a large lobulated heterogenously enhancing isodense mass causing expansile osteolytic destruction of the right mandibular angle-ramus, measuring 3.9x4.6x5.7 cm in transaxial and CC dimensions, probably a bony metastasis.
The right masseter muscle, anterior part of right parotid gland ( superficial and deep lobes), right medial pterygoid muscle, right submandibular gland appear to be compressed, Hypdense change of right masseter muscle is seen, could be due to edema.

A 0.5 cm rim enhancing nodule, likely a necrotic LN at right level Ib is noted.
Small nonspecific LNs at bilateral level I-V are observed.    
A 1.6 cm left posterior thyroidal nodule is seen.
The rest of the salivary glands and thyroid gland are unremarkable.

The pharynx, larynx, visualized upper esophagus are not remarkable.
The visualized brain demonstrates a 1.6 cm rim enhancing nodule at left occipital lobe with surrounding edema, likely a brain metastasis.
The orbits, mastoid air cells and the paranasal sinuses appear unremarkable.

A large heterogeneously enhancing mass at RUL, matted with enlarged heterogeneously enhancing mediastinal lymph nodes are noted, partially imaged, suggestive of CA lung with mediastinal lymph node metastases.
Peribronchial thickening/consolidation surrounding the RUL mass is noted, suspicious for lymphangitic obstruction or lymphangitis carcinomatosis.
A peripheral tiny nodule is seen ( IM230, SE 202), could be a lung metastasis.
A nodular ground glass opacity at superior segment of LLL is noted of uncertain nature.
Centrilobular emphysema of both visualized lungs with fibrosis/bronchiectasis at left apical lung is observed.

Cervical spondylosis with grade I retrolisthesis of C4-5, causing central spinal canal stenosis with cord compression at C4-5 is noted.

Impression:    
- A large lobulated heterogenously enhancing isodense mass causing expansile osteolytic destruction of the right mandibular angle-ramus, suggestive of a bony metastasis.
- A 0.5 cm rim enhancing nodule, likely a necrotic metastatic LN at right level Ib
- A 1.6 cm left posterior thyroidal nodule
- A 1.6 cm rim enhancing nodule at left occipital lobe with surrounding edema, likely a brain metastasis.
- A large RUL mass, matted with enlarged heterogeneously enhancing mediastinal lymph nodes, partially imaged, suggestive of CA lung with mediastinal lymph node metastases, with suspected lymphangitic obstruction or lymphangitis carcinomatosis. Full CT chest study is suggested.
- A peripheral tiny nodule ( IM230, SE 202), could be a lung metastasis.
- A nodular ground glass opacity at superior segment of LLL of uncertain nature.
- Cervical spondylosis with grade I retrolisthesis of C4-5, causing central spinal canal stenosis with cord compression at C4-5.

MDCT SCAN OF THE CHEST

History: RUL mass
Techniques: Plain and enhanced axial scans of the chest was performed according to the standard divisional protocol. Sagittal and coronal reformations were done.
Comparison: CT neck on 01/09/2023

Findings:
Lungs and pleural cavity: Centrilobular emphysema in both lungs.
A 5.2x4.6x7.5-cm heterogeneous enhancing mass at RUL, extending into RUL bronchus, resulting in RUL atelectasis. Multiple interlobular septal thickening with ground-glass opacities at RUL.
A 1.8-cm ground-glass nodule at superior segment of LLL.
Calcified granulomas with fibroatelectasis and bronchiectasis at LUL. Mild bronchiectasis in both lungs.
A few small nodular ground-glass opacities and centrilobular nodules at RML. A calcified nodule at RML.
Multiple centrilobular nodules at LLL. Subsegmental atelectases/fibroses in both lungs.
No pleural effusion. No pneumothorax.
Central airways: Patent.
Heart and great vessels: No cardiomegaly. Minimal pericardial effusion.
Mediastinum and hila: Multiple enlarged mediastinal and bronchopulmonary lymph nodes, up to 2.3 cm in short axis.
Chest wall and lower neck: A few bilateral SPC nodes, up to 1.2 cm in short axis. No axillary lymph node enlargement. Left thyroid nodule. A 4.6x1.1-cm fat-containing lesion at posterolateral aspect of left chest wall, probably lipoma.
Visualized upper abdomen: A few left adrenal masses, up to 4.4 cm. Nodular thickening at right adrenal gland. Multiple hypodense lesions in both hepatic lobes, up to 0.7 cm.
Bony structures and soft tissues: No suspicious osteolytic or blastic lesion.

Impression:
- A 5.2x4.6x7.5-cm heterogeneous enhancing mass at RUL, extending into RUL bronchus, resulting in RUL atelectasis. Such findings are concerning for primary lung cancer. Please correlate with tissue diagnosis.
- Multiple interlobular septal thickening with ground-glass opacities at RUL, probably lymphangitic spreading of tumor or lymphatic obstruction.
- A 1.8-cm ground-glass nodule at superior segment of LLL, probably infection/inflammation or pre-invasive lesion. Advise follow up.
- A few small nodular ground-glass opacities and centrilobular nodules at RML and centrilobular nodules at LLL, probably infection/inflammation. Please correlate with clinical context and other investigations.
- Evidence of smoking-related lung disease and old granulomatous infection.
- Multiple intrathoracic and SPC nodal metastasis.
- A few left adrenal masses, concerning for adrenal metastasis.
- Nodular thickening at right adrenal gland. Advise follow up.
- Multiple hypodense lesions in both hepatic lobes, indeterminate nature. Advise follow up.


Report Severity : Requires Attention

MDCT SCAN OF THE BRAIN
   
History: Case of CA lung with brain metastasis.

Technique:     Plain axial and enhanced CT scan of the brain was performed with 3 mm slice thickness.                    
Findings: The study reveals a small peripheral enhancing lesion at the left occipital lobe, measuring about 1.4x1.4 cm in size, could be intraparenchymal metastasis. Perilesional brain edema is detected. DDx: high grade glioma.
    Partially seen is the heterogeneous enhancing mass at the right masticator space, destructing the right mandibular ramus, suggested bone metastasis. Two focal osteolytic lesions at bilateral parietal bones are measuring about 0.8x1 cm and 0.9x1.3 cm in size, possible bone metastasis.
No definite leptomeningeal enhancement is noted.
Normal density of the rest brain parenchyma is seen. There is no acute infarction, acute intracerebral hemorrhage, extra-axial collection or brain herniation. No hydrocephalus is noted.
Evidence of bilateral lens extraction is noted, due to prior cataract surgery.
Mild mucosal thickening of bilateral frontal, bilateral ethmoid and bilateral maxillary sinuses is observed.
The rest orbits, the rest paranasal sinuses, nasopharynx and mastoid air cells are unremarkable.

Impression:
1.The 1.4x1.4-cm peripheral enhancing lesion at the left occipital lobe, could be intraparenchymal metastasis. DDx: high grade glioma
2.Two focal osteolytic lesions at bilateral parietal bones (0.8x1 cm and 0.9x1.3 cm in size), possible bone metastasis
3.Partially seen the heterogeneous enhancing mass at the right masticator space, destructing the right mandibular ramus, suggested bone metastasis

CT BRAIN WITH CONTRAST ENHANCEMENT


History: Advanced stage of NSCLC with left adrenal metastasis, start Erlotinib on 23/10/2024.

Technique: Plain and enhanced axial MDCT scan of the brain were performed with 3.0 mm slice thickness contiguously with multiplanar reformations.

Comparison: None

Findings: The study reveals normal gray-white differentiation of brain parenchyma. No evidence of brain swelling, intracranial mass or abnormal leptomeningeal enhancement is seen.  

The evaluation of brainstem and cerebellum is limited due to beam-hardening artifact. The visualized orbits, the paranasal sinuses, the mastoid air cells, the skull base, the calvarium are unremarkable.

Impression:
- No evidence of intracranial mass, abnormal leptomeningeal enhancement or osteolytic/ osteoblastic lesion to indicate metastasis is identified.
